questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss that started after a recent backpacking trip in Southeast Asia. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His leukocyte count is 7,500/mm3 (61% segmented neutrophils, 13% eosinophils, and 26% lymphocytes). Stool microscopy shows rhabditiform larvae. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hematuria is a common symptom of schistosomiasis, which is contracted when larvae penetrate the skin. Schistosoma species reproduce within the portal venous system and travel to the veins of target organs such as the bladder. Schistosoma species are endemic to many African countries, South America, and China, but not to Southeast Asia. Hematuria is not a common feature of strongyloidiasis.

B) CORRECT:

Strongyloides stercoralis is a nematode endemic to Southeast Asia that is transmitted via larval penetration of intact skin (usually when bare feet come into contact with contaminated soil). Larvae travel to the alveoli through the bloodstream, where they ascend the pulmonary system before being coughed up and swallowed. Once in the gastrointestinal tract, they become adult female worms and reproduce via parthenogenesis, with the eggs hatching as rhabditiform larvae. Rhabditiform larvae then become infective filariform larvae, penetrating intestinal mucosa or the skin of the perianal region, which completes the process of autoinfection. This results in a rapidly migrating (5 cm or more per hour) pink, raised track, referred to as larva currens; this is pathognomonic of Strongyloides infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Rectal prolapse is seen in children with trichuriasis, a whipworm (Trichuris trichiura) infection that is transmitted through ingestion of undercooked meat. Rectal prolapse is not a common feature of strongyloidiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Elephantiasis is characterized by lymphedema and is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti (roundworm). Lymphatic infiltration and obstruction by the worms leads to painful edema, lymphadenopathy, and fever. Lymphedema is not a feature of strongyloidiasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Focal neurologic deficits are seen in neurocysticercosis, which is caused by ingestion of Taenia solium eggs. They can also occur as a result of brain abscess formation, which may be seen in toxoplasmosis, a disease caused by ingestion of cysts present in contaminated cat feces and/or meat. Neurologic deficits are not a common feature of strongyloidiasis.

F) INCORRECT:

Muscle tenderness is a common finding of Trichinella spiralis infection. Trichinella is contracted through ingestion of undercooked pork and encysts within muscles, causing inflammation and myalgia. Strongyloides stercoralis does not cause muscle tenderness.
questions.hint: Rhabditiform larvae on stool microscopy, eosinophilia, and a recent travel history to Southeast Asia are consistent with Strongyloides stercoralis (threadworm) infection.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of abdominal pain and an itchy rash on his buttocks. He also has fever, nausea, and diarrhea with mucoid stools. One week ago, the patient returned from Indonesia, where he went for vacation. Physical examination shows erythematous, serpiginous lesions located in the perianal region and the posterior thighs. His leukocyte count is 9,000/mm3 with 25% eosinophils. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Giardia lamblia antibodies on stool immunoassay
Branching septate hyphae on KOH preparation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Detection of rhabditiform larvae on stool microscopy is diagnostic of strongyloidiasis. Strongyloides stercoralis is transmitted by larval penetration of intact skin (usually when bare feet come into contact with contaminated soil). Larvae travel to the alveoli through the bloodstream (pulmonary phase), where they ascend the pulmonary system to the pharynx before being coughed up and swallowed. Once in the gastrointestinal tract, they develop into adult female worms and reproduce via parthenogenesis, with the eggs hatching as rhabditiform larvae. Rhabditiform larvae then develop into infective filariform larvae, penetrating intestinal mucosa or the skin of the perianal region, which completes the process of autoinfection. This patient's serpiginous rash and gastrointestinal symptoms are manifestations of the cutaneous and intestinal phases of infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Detection of eggs on a tape test is diagnostic of enterobiasis, which causes nausea, abdominal pain, and pruritus. However, pruritus in enterobiasis is typically limited to the perianal region and is not associated with an erythematous, serpiginous rash extending onto the buttocks and thighs. Furthermore, this condition is most commonly seen in pediatric patients.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a specimen prepared by applying cellulose tape to the anal region of a patient (very high magnification)

Eight transparent, elongated oval eggs, which are flattened asymmetrically on one side can be seen.

C) INCORRECT:

Detection of oocysts on acid-fast stain is diagnostic of cryptosporidiosis. Abdominal pain, nausea, and persistent diarrhea are features of cryptosporidiosis and outbreaks occur worldwide, including Indonesia, especially among travelers. However, cryptosporidiosis would not explain this patient's eosinophilia and erythematous, serpiginous rash on his thighs and buttocks.

D) INCORRECT:

Detection of Giardia lamblia antibodies in the stool is diagnostic of giardiasis. Abdominal pain and diarrhea are features of giardiasis and infection is more likely after travel to a tropical region (e.g., Indonesia). However, giardiasis would not explain this patient's eosinophilia or erythematous, serpiginous rash on his thighs and buttocks.

E) INCORRECT:

Detection of branching septate hyphae on a KOH preparation is diagnostic of a dermatophyte infection (i.e., tinea), which typically manifests as a pruritic rash. However, the rash seen in tinea is characterized by pruritic plaques with central clearing and raised borders, in contrast to the erythematous, serpiginous rash seen in this patient. Furthermore, tinea infection does not typically cause systemic symptoms such as fever or intestinal symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, or diarrhea.
questions.hint: This patient's fever, gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain, nausea, and diarrhea), serpiginous rash, eosinophilia, and recent travel to a tropical area are highly suggestive of strongyloidiasis.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman from the Dominican Republic who has a history of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and hypothyroidism reports recurrent episodes of dark, tarry stools during the past 6 months and a 4-kg weight loss during the past year. She reports occasional diarrhea and mild abdominal pain. Two years ago, she was treated for Helicobacter pylori infection with a proton pump inhibitor, bismuth subsalicylate, metronidazole, and tetracycline.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a hemoglobin level of 8.0 g/dL (reference range, 12.0–16.0) and a leukocyte count of 8000 per mm3 (4500–11,000), with an absolute eosinophil count of 1230 per mm3 (0–350).
Upper endoscopy reveals moderate-to-severe duodenitis, and small-bowel biopsy demonstrates chronic inflammation in the lamina propria. No H. pylori organisms are identified.
Results from which one of the following tests are most likely to be diagnostic in this case?

choices.text: Helicobacter pylori immunoglobulin G antibody test
Periodic acid-Schiff staining of duodenal biopsy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A serum gastrin level test is used to diagnose Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, which is characterized by ulcers in the small bowel and stomach that are typically painful. Hypereosinophilia does not occur in this syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Helicobacter pylori infection is more common in patients from tropical and subtropical areas, but it is not associated with hypereosinophilia. If testing for H. pylori is needed, stool antigen or breath testing should be used.

C) CORRECT:

Strongyloidiasis is a parasitic infection endemic to tropical and subtropical regions. Both acute and chronic infections cause gastrointestinal bleeding secondary to mucosal ulceration. A patient from an endemic region who has gastrointestinal bleeding, hypereosinophilia, and evidence of duodenitis on endoscopy should undergo serological testing for Strongyloides. These tests are based on detecting IgG antibodies, which appear 6 weeks after the initial infection. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays have a sensitivity of 83% to 93%. IgG-based testing may give false negative results in early acute strongyloidiasis, but IgM-based testing is also unreliable in this context. Duodenal aspirates can be evaluated for a quicker diagnosis, but serologic testing has higher sensitivity. Serial stool microscopy can also be performed to detect Strongyloides larvae, which begin to appear in stool 3–4 weeks after the initial infection.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test for a patient from a subtropical country who presents with upper gastrointestinal bleeding, hypereosinophilia, and evidence of duodenitis on endoscopy is the measurement of Strongyloides immunoglobulin G antibodies.

D) INCORRECT:

A Giardia stool antigen test is used to diagnose giardiasis, which typically causes abdominal pain, diarrhea, bloating, and malabsorption but not gastrointestinal bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Upper endoscopy with small-bowel biopsies, looking for periodic acid-Schiff-positive macrophages, is the diagnostic test of choice for Whipple disease and is generally the first test performed for patients with suspected Whipple disease who have gastrointestinal symptoms. This condition is most common in men and causes weight loss and malabsorption. It does not typically cause hypereosinophilia or gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman who is originally from El Salvador and has a history of chronic myelogenous leukemia is hospitalized with a 4-day history of fever, abdominal pain, nausea, and diarrhea. She underwent chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide, vincristine, doxorubicin, and dexamethasone 30 days ago when she was found to be in blast crisis. She tolerated chemotherapy well at that time. She has no other known medical problems.
On examination, her temperature is 38.8°C, her heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and she has tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium and bilateral upper abdominal quadrants.
A CT scan of her abdomen demonstrates enteritis. Blood cultures from admission grow both Escherichia coli and Klebsiella pneumonia. A stool sample is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following parasitic infections is most likely causing the patient’s current clinical syndrome?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Enterobius vermicularis and Dracunculus medinensis are also nematodes and are the causative agents of pinworm and “guinea worm,” respectively. Neither would have this clinical presentation.

B) INCORRECT:

Enterobius vermicularis and Dracunculus medinensis are also nematodes and are the causative agents of pinworm and “guinea worm,” respectively. Neither would have this clinical presentation.

C) INCORRECT:

Taenia solium and Diphyllobothrium latum are cestodes (tapeworms) and would not have the rounded appearance of the worm in the image.

D) INCORRECT:

Taenia solium and Diphyllobothrium latum are cestodes (tapeworms) and would not have the rounded appearance of the worm in the image.

E) CORRECT:

Strongyloides stercoralis is an intestinal nematode (roundworm) estimated to infect approximately 100 million people worldwide. Infection typically occurs in tropical and subtropical regions when larvae penetrate the skin, often the soles of bare feet. The image shows a round worm with a blunt, tapered conical end consistent with S. stercoralis.

Strongyloides can establish an autoinfection cycle in humans, allowing hosts to remain subclinically infected for decades. Peripheral eosinophilia is seen in up to 75% of those chronically infected.

Immunosuppression, such as that resulting from chemotherapy and glucocorticoid use, is a risk factor for development of hyperinfection syndrome and disseminated strongyloidiasis. Hyperinfection syndrome occurs when filariform larvae penetrate the intestinal wall, enter the blood, and disseminate throughout the body, resulting in pulmonary infiltrates, enteritis, secondary gram-negative bacteremia, and occasionally meningitis due to bowel flora. The treatment of choice for Strongyloides infection is ivermectin.

Key learning point: The most likely underlying parasitic infection in an immunosuppressed patient with enteritis and polymicrobial gram-negative bacteremia is Strongyloides stercoralis infection.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with 4 weeks of intermittent abdominal pain, loose stools, and dry cough. He spent 18 months working on the northern border of Thailand with refugees from Myanmar and returned 3 weeks ago. He has a history of rheumatoid arthritis and is scheduled to start methotrexate therapy next month. Physical examination shows mild abdominal tenderness and the patient shows a photograph of a few linear urticarial lesions on his lower extremities that he had just before he left Thailand and that he thought was an allergic reaction to a plant. Laboratory studies show mild eosinophilia. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Obtain blood cultures and start broad-spectrum antibiotics
Obtain a urine sample for ova and parasites
Obtain strongyloidiasis serology and/or stool microscopy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures and broad-spectrum antibiotics are appropriate for bacterial sepsis, but this patient's clinical presentation and exposure history are more consistent with parasitic infection, for which a different initial diagnostic approach is needed.

B) INCORRECT:

Starting methotrexate without excluding strongyloidiasis is inappropriate because of the patient's exposure history and symptoms. Immunosuppression can precipitate hyperinfection syndrome, which can be life-threatening.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric therapy should only be considered if diagnostic testing cannot be obtained. This patient can undergo appropriate testing, and definitive diagnosis is preferred before initiating treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Urine microscopy is not indicated for the investigation of strongyloidiasis.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's clinical features and significant exposure history are suggestive of strongyloidiasis. As immunosuppression with methotrexate is planned in this patient, testing with both (the suggested diagnostic evaluation for immunocompromised patients) may be preferred to avoid a false-negative result, as immunosuppressed patients are at elevated risk of hyperinfection.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with a 4-day history of worsening abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and progressive dyspnea. He underwent renal transplantation 8 months ago and takes mycophenolate and prednisone. He emigrated from Honduras 2 years ago. Vital signs are BP, 95/55; P, 110; T, 38.2°C (100.8°F); oxygen saturation, 88% on room air. Physical examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness, bilateral pulmonary crackles, and a rash on his trunk. Laboratory studies show WBC 15,000/μL with 2% eosinophils. A photograph of the rash is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain blood cultures and begin empiric antibiotics
Order CT scan of chest and abdomen with IV and oral contrast
Perform stool microscopy and Strongyloides serology

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures are important given the risk of gram-negative bacteremia from migrating intestinal larva, but this approach does not identify the underlying parasitic infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Leishmaniasis manifests with distinctly different clinical features to those seen in this patient. Cutaneous leishmaniasis typically manifests as painless and reddish macules and papules that develop central ulceration, while visceral leishmaniasis causes spiking fevers, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia. The serpiginous rash, gastrointestinal symptoms, and pulmonary involvement in this immunosuppressed patient are characteristic of strongyloidiasis hyperinfection syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Imaging may show complications of hyperinfection syndrome but is not diagnostic for strongyloidiasis. The clinical presentation of strongyloidiasis requires specific parasitic testing to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has a history of renal transplantation, there is no evidence of renal disease. The priority is diagnosing and treating the underlying parasitic infection that is causing hyperinfection syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with classic features of strongyloidiasis hyperinfection syndrome: immunosuppression, endemic exposure history, gastrointestinal symptoms, pulmonary involvement, and larva currens rash. In immunosuppressed patients, both stool microscopy and serology are required because antibody responses may be impaired. The absence of eosinophilia is typical in hyperinfection syndrome.
